The morning mist clung to the rolling hills of Brecon like a familiar embrace, and Jonty Rhys-Davies could smell the petrichor rising from the dew-soaked earth as he stepped onto the first tee at Crickhowell Golf Club. His engineering mind automatically calculated wind speed, trajectory angles, and the precise arc needed for his opening drive, but today something felt different. Perhaps it was the way the early sunlight caught the distant mountains, or maybe it was simply that restless feeling he'd been carrying for weeks—a sense that his carefully ordered life was about to shift in ways he couldn't predict or control.

At thirty-two, Jonty had built himself a comfortable existence. His structural engineering consultancy in Cardiff was thriving, specializing in sustainable bridge designs that had earned him recognition throughout Wales and beyond. His semi-detached house in Pontcanna was mortgage-free, his pension contributions were on track, and his handicap had dropped to a respectable twelve over the past season. Everything was proceeding according to plan, yet lately he found himself staring out of his office window at the River Taff, wondering if there wasn't something more to life than load calculations and environmental impact assessments.

"You'll be wanting a caddy today, Mr. Rhys-Davies?" The voice belonged to Tommy Morgan, the club's head professional, whose weathered face had witnessed forty years of golfers' triumphs and disasters on these Welsh fairways.

Jonty shook his head automatically. "I usually prefer to carry my own bag, thanks Tommy. Helps me think through each shot without distraction."

"Ah, but today's different, see. We've got a new one started this week—keen as mustard and needs the experience. Ellis Pemberton, just moved down from Manchester. Bright kid, knows the game inside and out. Might be worth giving them a chance?"

Before Jonty could formulate a polite refusal, a figure emerged from the caddy shed, and his carefully rehearsed words evaporated like morning mist in sunshine. Ellis Pemberton was perhaps twenty-five, with auburn hair that caught the light and moved with an easy, athletic grace that spoke of someone completely comfortable in their own skin. When their eyes met, Jonty felt something shift in his chest—not the flutter of attraction he'd experienced before, but something deeper and more unsettling, like tectonic plates realigning beneath his feet.

"Morning," Ellis said, extending a hand that was firm and callused from honest work. "I promise I won't lose your ball in the rough or give you terrible yardages. Well, not intentionally anyway."

The smile that accompanied these words was crooked and entirely genuine, and Jonty found himself nodding agreement before his logical mind could intercede. "Jonty Rhys-Davies. I should warn you, I tend to overthink every shot. You might find it rather tedious."

"Nothing wrong with thinking things through properly. I'm studying sports science part-time at Cardiff Met, so I appreciate the analytical approach. Besides, there's usually more than one way to play any hole—sometimes it's good to talk through the options."

As they walked toward the first tee, Jonty noticed how Ellis moved with quiet confidence, studying the course layout with intelligent eyes. There was something refreshing about being around someone who seemed so genuinely enthusiastic about the game itself, rather than using golf as a networking opportunity or status symbol.

The first hole at Crickhowell was a relatively straightforward par four, but the elevated tee provided a spectacular view across the Usk Valley toward the Black Mountains. Jonty usually spent a moment appreciating the vista before focusing on his shot, but today he found himself acutely aware of Ellis standing nearby, pulling clubs from the bag and quietly assessing the conditions.

"Wind's coming from the southwest, quite gentle. Pin's positioned back right today, so you'll want to favor the left side of the fairway for the best angle in." Ellis's voice was matter-of-fact, professional. "What's your usual strategy here?"

It was a simple question, but somehow it opened something in Jonty. Instead of his typical silent routine, he found himself explaining his thought process—how he usually played conservatively with a seven iron to avoid the fairway bunkers, setting up a longer but safer second shot. Ellis listened attentively, nodding and asking follow-up questions that showed real understanding of course management.

"That's smart, but have you considered that the pin position today actually rewards aggression? If you could get your drive past those bunkers, you'd have a wedge in instead of a six iron. The green's quite receptive this time of morning—see how soft it looks?"

Jonty studied the hole again, this time through Ellis's eyes. The strategy made sense, but it required committing to a shot that was outside his comfort zone. "You think I should take driver then?"

"I think you should play the shot that feels right to you. I'm just pointing out that you've got options. Sometimes the safe play is actually riskier in the long run."

There was something in the way Ellis said this—with quiet conviction but no pressure—that made Jonty reach for his driver. As he addressed the ball, he felt unusually relaxed, as if Ellis's presence had somehow quieted the constant analytical chatter in his mind. The swing felt effortless, and the ball flew true and long, settling perfectly in the landing area Ellis had identified.

"Lovely strike," Ellis said, shouldering the bag. "That's opened up the whole green for you now."

Walking down the fairway together, Jonty found himself drawn into conversation in a way that felt both natural and unprecedented. Ellis asked thoughtful questions about his engineering work, showing genuine curiosity about the technical challenges involved in designing sustainable structures. In return, Jonty learned that Ellis had moved to Wales after finishing a degree in Sports Management, drawn by the quality of life and the opportunity to work outdoors while continuing studies.

The second shot was indeed a simple wedge, and Ellis's read of the green proved accurate—the ball checked nicely and settled eight feet from the pin. As Jonty lined up the birdie putt, he felt a strange combination of nervousness and excitement that had nothing to do with making or missing the putt.

"Just trust your stroke," Ellis said quietly. "You've got good hands—let them do the work."

The ball rolled true into the center of the cup, and Jonty's smile felt broader than any birdie warranted. Ellis's answering grin was equally enthusiastic, as if they'd achieved something significant together.

The round continued in this vein—Ellis providing insights and encouragement while Jonty found himself playing with a freedom and confidence he'd rarely experienced. They talked about everything and nothing: Ellis's love of hiking in Snowdonia, Jonty's work on a new pedestrian bridge in Swansea, their shared appreciation for good coffee and terrible Welsh weather jokes.

By the time they reached the par-three thirteenth, Jonty realized he was playing the best golf of his life, but more importantly, he was enjoying himself in a way that transcended the game itself. Ellis had a gift for being fully present in each moment, finding genuine delight in well-struck shots and viewing poor ones as interesting puzzles to solve rather than failures to lament.

"This hole always gives me trouble," Jonty admitted, looking at the elevated green protected by bunkers and a small pond. "I usually aim for the fat part of the green and hope for the best."

Ellis studied the pin position and nodded thoughtfully. "Safe strategy, but look at where that pin is—front left, just over the bunker. If you could trust your swing, you could attack it with a sand wedge. Take the water completely out of play and give yourself a realistic birdie chance."

"That's a pretty aggressive line. What if I catch it a bit thin?"

"Then you'll probably end up in the bunker, and you'll play out for bogey. But what if you don't? What if you trust yourself and hit it exactly where you're aiming?"

There was something in Ellis's voice—not quite challenging, but encouraging in a way that made Jonty want to rise to the occasion. He selected the sand wedge and took several practice swings, feeling Ellis's quiet confidence beside him.

The shot felt perfect from the moment it left the clubface, arcing high against the blue sky and landing softly on the green, rolling to within four feet of the pin. Ellis's whoop of delight was infectious, and Jonty found himself laughing with pure joy.

"That was brilliant! Absolutely perfect commitment to the shot. How did that feel?"

"Like I actually knew what I was doing for once," Jonty replied, still grinning. "I can't remember the last time I attacked a pin like that."

"Maybe you just needed someone to remind you that you're better than you think you are."As they walked toward the green, Jonty found himself studying Ellis's profile in the afternoon light. There was something compelling about the way Ellis approached each hole with fresh curiosity, never seeming to tire of the strategic puzzles the course presented. When Ellis crouched down to read the line of Jonty's putt, pointing out the subtle break that Jonty had missed, their faces were close enough that Jonty could see the flecks of gold in Ellis's hazel eyes. The moment stretched longer than it should have, and when Ellis looked up, something unspoken passed between them that made Jonty's pulse quicken in a way that had nothing to do with the prospect of making another birdie.

The putt rolled in smoothly, and as they walked to the next tee, Jonty realized that somewhere over the past three hours, his entire perspective had shifted. Golf had always been a solitary pursuit for him—a chance to work through problems in his head while moving through the familiar rhythms of the game. But playing with Ellis felt like a conversation in itself, each shot building on the last, creating something richer and more complex than either of them could achieve alone. It reminded him of his favorite engineering projects, where the collaboration between designer and builder resulted in structures more elegant and enduring than either could envision independently.

The fourteenth hole was a long par five that typically required three careful shots to reach the green safely. Jonty's drive found the center of the fairway, leaving him with about two hundred and forty yards to the pin. Ellis pulled the bag to a halt and began examining the lie, the wind conditions, and the layout of the green with the intensity of someone solving a particularly interesting equation. After a moment of consideration, Ellis pulled out Jonty's three wood and held it out with a questioning look.

"I know it's not the percentage play, but you've got a perfect lie and the wind's helping. The green's angled to accept a shot from this position, and there's plenty of room to miss left or right without serious trouble. You've been striking the ball beautifully all day—why not see what happens when you really commit to a shot?" Ellis paused, then added with that crooked smile, "Besides, the worst thing that happens is you end up with a short iron into the green instead of a wedge. Not exactly a disaster."

Jonty took the three wood and addressed the ball, feeling that same sense of relaxed confidence that had been building throughout the round. The swing felt smooth and powerful, and he watched with satisfaction as the ball flew high and straight, carrying the fairway bunkers and rolling onto the front edge of the green, finishing about thirty feet from the pin. Ellis's enthusiastic response made him feel like he'd just accomplished something genuinely impressive, rather than simply executing a golf shot that would have been routine for a better player.

Walking up to the green together, Jonty found himself sharing stories about his work that he'd never told anyone outside the engineering community. He described the satisfaction of seeing a bridge design come together, the way all the calculations and stress analyses transformed into something tangible that would serve people for decades to come. Ellis listened with genuine interest, asking insightful questions about the creative aspects of engineering that most people never considered. In return, Ellis talked about the psychology of athletic performance, about how confidence and doubt could transform the same physical capabilities into completely different outcomes.

"It's fascinating how much of any sport happens between your ears," Ellis said as they lined up Jonty's eagle putt. "You've got all the technical skills you need—better than most amateurs I've worked with. But you spend so much energy managing your expectations that you don't always let yourself play freely. Today feels different though. You're trusting your instincts more."

The observation was accurate in a way that made Jonty slightly uncomfortable. He'd always prided himself on his analytical approach to problems, but Ellis was suggesting that perhaps overthinking could be a limitation as well as a strength. The eagle putt missed by inches, rolling just past the hole, but the tap-in birdie felt like a significant accomplishment rather than a minor disappointment. As they walked to the fifteenth tee, Jonty realized that his usual post-shot analysis had been replaced by a more immediate appreciation for the experience itself.

The final four holes passed in a blur of excellent golf and increasingly easy conversation. Ellis's course management advice proved consistently sound, but more importantly, their partnership seemed to bring out qualities in Jonty's game that he'd never fully accessed before. He found himself taking calculated risks that would have seemed foolish during his usual solitary rounds, and more often than not, his increased commitment to each shot produced better results than his typically cautious approach.

By the time they reached the eighteenth green, Jonty had shot seventy-nine—five strokes better than his previous best score at Crickhowell. But as he marked his scorecard, the number seemed less important than the realization that he hadn't wanted the round to end. The prospect of returning to his normal routine—the drive back to Cardiff, the evening spent reviewing project specifications, the familiar solitude of his well-ordered life—suddenly felt less appealing than it had in years.

Ellis helped him clean his clubs and organize his bag with the same attention to detail that had characterized the entire round. As they walked back toward the clubhouse, Jonty found himself searching for a way to extend their time together without seeming presumptuous or inappropriate. The easy camaraderie they'd developed over eighteen holes felt too valuable to simply walk away from, but he wasn't sure how to translate it into something beyond the professional relationship of golfer and caddy.

"That was exceptional," he finally said as they reached the parking area. "I can't remember enjoying a round of golf more, and I certainly can't remember playing better. Thank you for pushing me out of my comfort zone."

Ellis's smile in response was warm and genuine, but Jonty thought he detected something else there as well—perhaps the same reluctance to see their time together end. "You made it easy. Most players either want a caddy to just carry their bag and stay quiet, or they want someone to tell them exactly what to do on every shot. You found the perfect balance—open to suggestions but confident enough to make your own decisions. It was a pleasure to watch you play."

They stood there for a moment in the late afternoon sunlight, and Jonty felt the weight of opportunity and uncertainty settling around them like the lengthening shadows across the car park. He wanted to suggest dinner, or drinks, or simply another round of golf soon, but something held him back. Perhaps it was the fear of misreading the situation, or maybe it was the deeper concern that pursuing whatever was developing between them might complicate his carefully structured life in ways he wasn't prepared to handle.**Chapter 2**

The drive back to Cardiff felt longer than usual, though Jonty couldn't decide if time was moving slowly because he was reluctant to leave the afternoon behind or because his mind kept circling back to moments from the round that seemed to shimmer with significance he couldn't quite name. The A470 wound through valleys that he'd traveled countless times, but tonight the familiar landscape seemed subtly transformed, as if his conversation with Ellis had adjusted some internal lens through which he viewed the world. He found himself remembering not just the golf shots—though those had been remarkably satisfying—but the way Ellis had listened when he talked about his work, asking questions that revealed genuine curiosity rather than polite interest.

His house in Pontcanna welcomed him with its usual quiet efficiency. The mail was stacked neatly on the hall table where Mrs. Jenkins, his twice-weekly cleaner, always left it. The refrigerator hummed contentedly, well-stocked with the sort of sensible meals that a successful bachelor was supposed to prefer. Everything was exactly as he'd left it that morning, yet somehow the familiar surroundings felt slightly hollow, as if the day's experiences had created a need for something more substantial than his typically solitary evening routine. He poured himself a glass of the good Welsh whisky he saved for special occasions, though he wasn't entirely sure what he was celebrating, and settled into his favorite armchair with a stack of technical journals that had arrived during the week.

The articles on sustainable construction materials and innovative bridge design techniques—topics that usually captured his complete attention—seemed unable to hold his focus tonight. Instead, he found himself thinking about Ellis's observation that he possessed more skill than he typically allowed himself to demonstrate. The comment had been made in the context of golf, but it nagged at him in a way that suggested broader applications. How many other areas of his life had he approached with excessive caution, choosing safety over the possibility of genuine achievement or fulfillment? His engineering career was successful by any reasonable measure, but he'd always chosen projects that played to his established strengths rather than pushing into unexplored territory. Even his personal life reflected the same pattern—comfortable routines and predictable pleasures that never demanded too much emotional risk or vulnerability.

Saturday morning arrived gray and drizzling, the sort of Welsh weather that made staying indoors with coffee and the weekend papers feel like the most sensible option. Jonty had planned to spend the day working on a proposal for a pedestrian bridge in Newport, a project that excited him because it would incorporate some innovative materials he'd been researching. But as he spread the plans across his dining table and began reviewing the structural calculations, his concentration kept drifting back to memories of yesterday's round. He found himself wondering what Ellis was doing on this rain-soaked morning, whether they were working at the golf club or perhaps studying for their sports science degree. The curiosity felt both natural and slightly intrusive, as if he was developing an interest in someone's life without having been invited to do so.

By noon, the rain had intensified to the point where even the most dedicated golfers would likely postpone their rounds. Jonty made a decision that surprised him with its spontaneity—he would drive back to Crickhowell, ostensibly to speak with Tommy Morgan about booking a series of lessons to build on yesterday's breakthrough, but really hoping for a chance to see Ellis again. The justification felt thin even to his own analytical mind, but something about the prospect of another conversation with the young caddy seemed worth the hour's drive through increasingly unpleasant weather. As he pulled on his waterproof jacket and headed for the car, he caught himself taking a bit more care with his appearance than a simple trip to the golf club typically warranted.

The drive to Brecon tested his resolve as the rain hammered against the windscreen and the wipers struggled to maintain visibility. Traffic moved at a crawl through the valleys, and twice he considered turning back to the comfort of his warm house and the abandoned bridge proposal. But something kept him moving forward—perhaps the same instinct that had led him to take Ellis's advice on aggressive shots yesterday, the growing sense that his habitual caution might be costing him more than it was protecting. The golf club car park was nearly empty when he arrived, just a few dedicated staff vehicles and the kind of serious golfers who viewed adverse weather as an interesting additional challenge rather than a reason to stay home.

Tommy Morgan looked genuinely surprised to see him pushing through the clubhouse doors, shaking raindrops from his jacket and stamping water from his shoes. The head professional was sitting behind the counter, working on what appeared to be inventory lists while the weather kept most of his usual business at bay. His weathered face broke into a welcoming smile as Jonty approached, though his eyes held a hint of curiosity about what would bring someone out on such an unpleasant day for what was clearly not going to be a round of golf.

"Afternoon, Mr. Rhys-Davies! Not exactly prime golfing conditions today, is it? Though I suppose you engineers are used to working in all kinds of weather." Tommy's greeting was warm and professional, but Jonty detected a note of gentle teasing in his voice, as if the older man suspected there might be more to this visit than a simple desire to discuss golf instruction. "What brings you out on such a miserable day? Don't tell me you're thinking of playing eighteen holes in this weather—I'd have to question your judgment even more than I usually do."

Jonty found himself somewhat at a loss for how to explain his presence without revealing the true motivation for the drive. The story about wanting to book lessons felt increasingly flimsy now that he was actually standing in the clubhouse, surrounded by the quiet atmosphere of a golf facility essentially shut down by weather. Instead, he found himself asking about yesterday's round, mentioning how much he'd enjoyed working with Ellis and wondering if they might be available for future rounds. The question felt loaded with implications that he wasn't ready to examine too closely, but Tommy's response suggested that his interest was being interpreted as nothing more than a satisfied customer hoping to repeat a positive experience.

"Ah, young Ellis made quite an impression then? I'm not surprised—they've got a real gift for reading both courses and players. Been working with golfers since they were barely old enough to carry a bag, from what I understand. Their father was a club professional up in Manchester before he retired." Tommy paused in his inventory work and gave Jonty his full attention, clearly pleased to discuss one of his staff members' success. "Ellis mentioned having a particularly good round yesterday, said they'd worked with a player who really listened to advice and wasn't afraid to try new approaches. I take it that was you?"

The conversation continued for several minutes, with Tommy sharing more details about Ellis's background and experience while Jonty tried to extract information without seeming overly curious. He learned that Ellis typically worked weekends at the club while attending Cardiff Metropolitan University during the week, pursuing a degree that combined sports science with business management. The schedule suggested someone who was serious about building a career in golf, but who also understood the importance of education and long-term planning. Jonty found himself impressed by Ellis's apparent combination of passion and practicality, qualities that resonated with his own approach to professional development.

As their conversation was winding down, Ellis emerged from the equipment room carrying what appeared to be a set of freshly cleaned clubs, clearly taking advantage of the slow day to catch up on maintenance tasks that might be neglected during busier periods. They looked surprised to see Jonty standing at the counter, and he felt a moment of awkwardness about how to explain his presence without admitting that he'd driven an hour through terrible weather primarily in hopes of continuing their acquaintance. Ellis's smile, however, suggested genuine pleasure at seeing him again, and any discomfort Jonty felt about his motivations dissolved in the warmth of that welcome.

"This is unexpected—I thought everyone with sense would be staying indoors today," Ellis said, setting down the clubs and approaching the counter where Jonty and Tommy were chatting. "Please tell me you're not planning to play golf in this weather. I'm all for dedication to the game, but there's a difference between commitment and masochism." The gentle teasing in Ellis's voice carried none of the awkwardness that Jonty had been feeling about his presence at the club, suggesting that whatever had prompted his visit, it wasn't unwelcome.

Jonty explained his nominal purpose—discussing the possibility of regular lessons and perhaps booking Ellis as a caddy for future rounds—while Ellis listened with what seemed like genuine interest. The practical arrangements provided a comfortable framework for conversation, but underneath the discussion of scheduling and availability, Jonty sensed the same easy connection that had developed during yesterday's round. When Ellis suggested that they might combine formal instruction with on-course play, creating a more comprehensive approach to improving his game, Jonty found himself agreeing more quickly than his usual careful consideration of new commitments would typically allow.

Tommy excused himself to handle some administrative tasks, leaving Jonty and Ellis alone in the quiet clubhouse with rain pattering against the windows and the distant sound of water running off the roof. The intimate atmosphere seemed to encourage more personal conversation, and Ellis began sharing details about their transition from Manchester to Wales, describing the appeal of studying at Cardiff Met while working in the more relaxed environment of Welsh golf clubs. Jonty found himself reciprocating with stories about his own journey from university to professional independence, the challenges of building a consulting practice, and the satisfaction of seeing his designs become permanent parts of the landscape.

"I've always been fascinated by bridges," Ellis said when Jonty mentioned his specialization in pedestrian and cycling infrastructure. "There's something almost poetic about creating connections between places that were previously separated. It must be incredibly satisfying to know that your work helps people reach places they couldn't get to before, or makes their journeys safer and more pleasant." The observation revealed a perspective on his profession that Jonty hadn't expected from someone outside the engineering field, a recognition that his work had aesthetic and social dimensions beyond the technical challenges that typically occupied his attention.

Their conversation meandered through topics that seemed only loosely connected but somehow formed a coherent exploration of their respective approaches to work, creativity, and the balance between security and adventure. Ellis spoke eloquently about the psychology of athletic performance, drawing parallels between the mental aspects of golf and other life challenges that required confidence in the face of uncertainty. Jonty found himself sharing thoughts about engineering philosophy that he'd never articulated before, ideas about how the best structural solutions often emerged from embracing rather than avoiding complexity and ambiguity.

As the afternoon progressed and the rain showed no signs of abating, their discussion became increasingly personal without ever feeling invasive or premature. Ellis talked about the decision to leave Manchester, describing a sense that they had outgrown the opportunities available there and needed a change of environment to discover what they might be capable of achieving. Jonty recognized something familiar in that restlessness, the feeling that a comfortable but constrained situation might be preventing rather than enabling personal growth. He found himself admitting to similar feelings about his own life, the sense that his success had created a kind of golden cage that protected him from failure but also from the possibility of discovering untapped potential.

When Tommy returned from his office tasks, he found them deep in conversation about the relationship between risk and reward in both golf and life, their discussion animated by the kind of intellectual engagement that both clearly enjoyed. The head professional smiled knowingly as he observed their rapport, but made no comment beyond suggesting that they might want to consider moving their conversation to the clubhouse bar, where they could continue talking in more comfortable surroundings while the weather continued its assault on the Welsh countryside.

The bar area was nearly deserted except for two older members who were playing cards in the corner and seemed entirely absorbed in their game. Ellis and Jonty settled into chairs near the windows overlooking the course, where they could watch the rain creating temporary streams across fairways and greens while continuing their wide-ranging conversation. Jonty ordered a pint of the local bitter while Ellis chose coffee, explaining that they had studying to do later and needed to maintain some level of mental clarity. The difference in their choices highlighted the gap in their ages and life stages, but somehow it didn't create any sense of incompatibility or awkwardness between them.**Chapter 3**

The following Tuesday found Jonty staring at his computer screen in his Cardiff office, ostensibly reviewing structural calculations for a new cycling bridge in Swansea, but actually finding his attention wandering to thoughts of Saturday's conversation with Ellis. The rain had eventually stopped around five o'clock, and they'd spent another hour walking around the clubhouse grounds, Ellis pointing out subtle features of the course design that revealed themselves only to someone who'd studied the layout with genuine care and attention. Their conversation had ranged from golf course architecture to sustainable engineering practices, creating connections between their respective fields that neither had anticipated. When they'd finally parted ways in the car park, Ellis had mentioned being free the following weekend if Jonty wanted to schedule that lesson they'd discussed, and the prospect had been occupying far more of his mental energy than any upcoming golf instruction reasonably should.

The bridge project demanded his full attention—it was an innovative design that would span the River Tawe while incorporating renewable energy generation through integrated solar panels and small wind turbines. The technical challenges were exactly the sort that typically energized him, requiring creative solutions to balance structural integrity with environmental sensitivity and aesthetic appeal. Yet today he found himself thinking about Ellis's observation that bridges were fundamentally about creating connections, about enabling journeys that previously seemed impossible or impractical. The comment had revealed an intuitive understanding of why he'd chosen this particular engineering specialty, recognizing the human dimension of infrastructure in a way that even some of his professional colleagues missed. The memory of that conversation kept pulling his focus away from stress calculations and material specifications, creating an unusual restlessness that made his normally productive work environment feel confining.

By Wednesday afternoon, he'd made the decision to call Crickhowell and book a formal lesson with Ellis for the weekend. The justification was entirely reasonable—his improved performance during their previous round clearly demonstrated that professional instruction could benefit his game, and Ellis had shown both technical knowledge and teaching instincts that promised continued improvement. The fact that he was looking forward to seeing Ellis again with an anticipation that had little to do with golf instruction was something he chose not to examine too closely. When Tommy Morgan answered the phone and confirmed Ellis's availability for Saturday morning, Jonty felt a surge of satisfaction that seemed disproportionate to the simple scheduling of a golf lesson.

Thursday brought unseasonably warm weather that had him opening windows in his office for the first time in months, letting fresh spring air circulate through the space while he worked on preliminary designs for a pedestrian bridge that would connect two sections of Cardiff's expanding cycling network. The project excited him because it would serve both practical transportation needs and create a landmark feature that could become part of the city's identity. As he sketched initial concepts, he found himself wondering what Ellis would think of the design challenges involved in creating structures that were both functional and beautiful. The thought surprised him—he'd never before found himself seeking imaginary approval from someone outside the engineering profession, yet Ellis's appreciation for the poetic aspects of bridge building had resonated with him in a way that made their perspective seem valuable and worth considering.

His sister Cerys called that evening, her weekly check-in that usually focused on family news and gentle inquiries about his social life. Tonight, however, she seemed to sense some change in his mood, commenting that he sounded more animated than usual and wondering if anything interesting was happening in his typically predictable routine. Jonty found himself mentioning his recent golf experiences, describing his improved play and the excellent caddy who'd helped him achieve it. Cerys, who knew him well enough to read between the lines of his carefully neutral descriptions, asked several follow-up questions that made him realize he'd been talking about Ellis with more enthusiasm than he'd intended to reveal. When she suggested that it sounded like he'd made an interesting new friend, he agreed readily while simultaneously wondering if friendship was an adequate description of what seemed to be developing between them.

Friday afternoon brought an unexpected phone call from Tommy Morgan, who explained that Ellis had asked him to reach out about possibly moving Saturday's lesson to Sunday morning instead. A family situation had arisen that required Ellis to travel to Manchester over the weekend, but they were hoping to be back by Sunday and didn't want to cancel the lesson entirely. Tommy's tone suggested that Ellis had been particularly concerned about disappointing Jonty, which seemed to indicate a level of personal investment that extended beyond normal professional courtesy. Jonty quickly agreed to the schedule change, finding that his disappointment about the delay was balanced by pleasure at Ellis's apparent concern for his convenience and continued interest in working together.

Saturday morning found him at loose ends, his usual weekend routines disrupted by the cancelled lesson. He drove out to the Brecon Beacons for a solo hike, choosing a challenging route up Pen y Fan that would demand enough physical effort to quiet his restless energy. The weather was perfect for walking—clear skies and mild temperatures that brought out families and serious hikers alike. As he climbed steadily upward through landscapes that had been familiar since childhood, he found himself thinking about Ellis's descriptions of hiking in Snowdonia, trying to imagine them navigating mountain paths with the same thoughtful attention they brought to reading golf courses. The visualization came easily, suggesting that his interest in Ellis was expanding beyond their shared golfing experiences into curiosity about their broader approach to life and adventure.

The summit provided spectacular views across valleys that held decades of his own memories—school trips, family outings, solo expeditions during university breaks when he'd needed to clear his head before exams or major decisions. Today's climb felt different, though, charged with the kind of anticipation that usually preceded significant changes in his life. As he ate his packed lunch while surveying the familiar landscape spread below, he acknowledged to himself that his interest in Ellis had evolved beyond simple attraction to someone who'd helped improve his golf game. The conversations they'd shared revealed intellectual compatibility and emotional resonance that felt rare and worth exploring, regardless of where such exploration might lead. The admission felt both liberating and slightly frightening, opening possibilities that his carefully structured life hadn't accommodated before.

Sunday morning arrived with the promise of perfect golfing weather—clear skies, light winds, and temperatures warm enough to make early morning play comfortable. Jonty arrived at Crickhowell thirty minutes before his scheduled lesson, partly from habitual punctuality and partly from eagerness to resume his acquaintance with Ellis. The drive through the Welsh countryside had felt like a homecoming, though he couldn't decide whether he was returning to a place or to a person who'd begun to feel significant in ways he was still discovering. Tommy Morgan greeted him with the news that Ellis had indeed returned from Manchester the previous evening and was looking forward to their session, adding with a knowing smile that the young caddy had seemed particularly pleased that Jonty had been willing to reschedule rather than cancel entirely.

Ellis emerged from the pro shop carrying a clipboard and wearing the kind of focused expression that suggested they'd spent time preparing for the lesson. Their greeting was warm but professional, with an undercurrent of personal connection that made Jonty feel welcomed rather than merely accommodated. As they walked toward the practice range, Ellis explained their teaching philosophy—that improvement came from understanding not just the mechanics of good technique, but also the mental and strategic aspects that allowed players to access their best performance under various conditions. The approach resonated with Jonty's engineering mindset, which naturally sought to understand systems comprehensively rather than addressing isolated problems without considering broader contexts.

The lesson began with Ellis observing Jonty's swing with various clubs, taking notes and occasionally asking him to describe what he was feeling during different parts of his motion. Rather than immediately suggesting changes, Ellis seemed determined to understand Jonty's natural tendencies and existing strengths before identifying areas for improvement. The diagnostic approach felt respectful and intelligent, acknowledging that effective instruction needed to build on individual characteristics rather than imposing generic solutions. After twenty minutes of observation and analysis, Ellis began offering specific suggestions that were clearly tailored to Jonty's particular combination of physical capabilities and mental approach to the game.

"You've got excellent fundamentals," Ellis said as they moved from the driving range to the putting green. "Your swing is mechanically sound and repeatable, which is why you can play to your handicap consistently. But I think you're leaving shots on the course by being too conservative in your club selection and course management. Yesterday's round showed what happens when you trust your abilities and commit fully to your shots—you played at least three strokes better than your usual standard." The observation echoed thoughts that had been developing in Jonty's own mind, the recognition that his analytical nature sometimes led to overthinking that interfered with natural athletic ability.

The putting portion of the lesson revealed similar patterns—technically proficient execution hampered by excessive caution and second-guessing. Ellis introduced exercises designed to improve his green reading skills while also building confidence in his stroke under pressure.
